conclusion: To determine how the shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves backward, we need to analyze the geometry and relative positions of the objects and their shadows.
A (paper): The shadow is short, indicating the light is close to the object.
B (ball): The shadow is small and round, indicating the light is close and directly above the ball.
C (cylinder): The shadow is elongated, indicating the light source is at a lower angle.
D (waffle): The shadow is defined and slightly elongated.
As the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light and the objects. This generally results in smaller shadows because the light rays are more parallel.
A (paper): The shadow will move further away from the paper and become smaller and more defined.
B (ball): The shadow will move slightly further from the ball and become smaller.
C (cylinder): The shadow will move further away from the cylinder and become smaller and more elongated.
D (waffle): The shadow will move further away from the waffle and become smaller and more defined.

When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows (A, B, C, D) will move further away from their respective objects and become smaller and more defined due to the increased distance from the light source.
